subject: Public Speaking
title: Inductive Reasoning and Storytelling
description: A quick, practical guide to Inductive Reasoning and Storytelling.

hook.text: Here's one example. Here's another. And another. See the pattern? That's inductive reasoningâ€”it feels like storytelling.

buildup.text: Inductive arguments build from specific examples to a general conclusion. The more examples, the stronger the case.

discovery.text: TED talks use inductive structure: story, story, insight. It feels natural because we're wired for pattern recognition.

twist.text: The weakness: your conclusion is only probable, never certain. One counterexample can undermine an inductive argument.

climax.text: Inductive reasoning is weaker logically but stronger emotionally. People remember stories better than syllogisms.

punchline.text: Stack enough stories and the audience draws your conclusion for you.

quiz.question: How does inductive reasoning work in speeches?
options: It builds from specific examples to a general conclusion
